bibl.title: Letter from Merritte W. Ireland to Philip Showalter Hench, October 22, 1941

div1.p: Ireland requests twelve reprints of Hench's article on yellow fever. He reports that Truby has almost finished writing his manuscript, and agrees with Hench that it could be better published by someone other than the Surgeon General's Office.

div1.head: Letter from Merritte W. Ireland to Philip Showalter Hench, October 22, 1941
div1.opener:
1870 Wyoming Ave.,
Washington, D.C.,
October 22, 1941
Doctor Philip S. Hench,
The Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minn.
My dear Doctor Hench:
div1.p:
Thank you very much for your nice letter of Octo-
ber 16th with inclosures. Of course, the copy of General
Order #6 is for you. While I was getting, I got four copies.
I had a letter from Truby yesterday saying that it will take
but a very short time now for him to complete his manuscript.
What you say about the publication is very interesting and I
hope it can be done in a satisfactory way. Of course, The
Bulletin is not an attractive publication. It is put out
to get information to Medical Officers of the Army, Reserve
and National Guard. I talked to Kean yesterday about your
suggestions.

Thank you very much, I will be very glad to have
a dozen copies of the Hygeia reprints. That is very nice of
you.

I am sorry you had to be laid up. You are such a
busy man that I am sure such things are most distressing to
you.
div1.closer: Very sincerely yours, M. W. Ireland *ML
